heisig_chinese_memo: Pictograph of a child. The body looks like the number seven (a childhood age) and the horizontal stroke going through it are the arms.
heisig_story: This kanji is a pictograph of a child wrapped up in one of those handy cocoons that Japanese mothers fix to their backs to carry around young children who cannot get around by themselves. The first stroke is like a wee head popping out for air; the second shows the body and legs all wrapped up; and the final stroke shows the arms sticking out to cling to the mother's neck.

WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The child radical and the child kanji are exactly the same.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: So, if you know your radicals, you know your kanji as well! This won't last forever (where radicals are exactly the same as the kanji) so enjoy it while the kanji are still small and simple!
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic:
To remember the sounds ã— and ã™ we'll use these mnemonics:
There is a child standing in front of you. You look closely at the child but something seems wrong. You rub your eyes and when you open them again there is a sheep (ã—) in a suit (ã™) in front of you. You yelp, blink, and it's back to being a child. Are... all children really just sheep in suits?!
WaniKani_Reading_Info: The child runs away and you chase after it. Every time it's about to turn a corner it looks like a sheep in a suit again, but whenever you yell and point, it turns back. You're the only one who can see this sheep suit child!!

chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: Pictograph of a child. The body looks like the number seven (a childhood age) and the horizontal stroke going through it are the arms.
origin_of_ch_char_book: In ancient times people made a rope by combining straws one after another. When they made ropes, they thought of the ropes as symbolizing the descendants because of how the rope continues on. The (å­«, å­™, sun, grandchild) reflects their thoughts. The character symbolizes â€œgrandchildâ€ by combining child (å­, zi=tzu, child) and rope (çµ², ä¸, si=ssu, silk). These two combinations came to mean future generation, the descendants, or a grandchild.,What do you think (èº«, shen, body) is? It used to mean a pregnant woman with a child inside her. Now it means â€œbodyâ€. At long last, the woman gives birth to a baby. describes a woman giving birth to a child (å­, zi=tzu, child), bleeding blood . This character has changed to (è‚², yu=yÃ¼, give birth to, bring up), a newborn child and flesh (è‚‰, rou, flesh), meaning that a new born child is gradually growing up. After giving birth, she breastfeeds the baby. shows a mother with her breast out to feed the baby and the baby trying to suckle. A mother embracing the child feels so happy, this character means â€˜goodâ€™, â€˜likeâ€™. And the shape was also changed as (å¥½, hao, good;love).,In ancient East Asia, women often carried their children on their backs. The baby feels protected and attached to the mother in this way (ä¿, bao, protect). This symbol combines a human (äºº, ren, human) with a child on the right (å­, zi=tzu, child) and two points which indicate a pair of hands holding the child. It shows a human carrying a child on his/her back. Now the word has come to mean to â€œprotectâ€. On the other hand, (æ£„, å¼ƒ, qi=châ€™i, abandon) shows a different scene. A child (å­, zi=tzu, child), just born with blood on the skin, is on top of a straw basket (å…¶, qi=châ€™i, that) and two hands are holding them from below. What is going on? Many people had to abandon their babies due to illness or famine when food was scarce. This character describes such a sad situation. Someone is throwing his/her baby in the basket.
humanum_full_description_en:
Elaboration: In the bronze inscription, the character " ğ¢€ˆ " resembles a newborn child with hair on the head and two feet underneath (such as åˆ©ç°‹). This configuration is more complicated and used as the first " child " of the earthly branches. Since the word " ğ¢€ˆ " is very commonly used in oracle bone inscriptions , there are also simplified glyphs, such as omitting the two legs. In oracle bone inscriptions, Simplified Chinese was used in the early days, but the more complicated traditional forms were used in the late. After the beginning of the week, the " ğ¢€ˆ " used as the number one earthly branch was often replaced with " zi ", and the shape of " ğ¢€ˆ " gradually disappeared.

As for the character "å­", like a child with a larger head waving his hands, the direction of the ancient characters is often not fixed, so the character "å­" can be written to the left or right. The word "å­" can be used to indicate a boy or the sixth position of the earthly branch (ie, the word " si " in later generations). Since the word " ğ¢€ˆ " used as the number one earthly branch is gradually replaced by " zi ", there are two " zi " in the oracle bone inscriptions . To avoid confusion after Zhou, the word " Si " was used to denote the sixth position of the earthly branches.

" Child " originally refers to an appellation relative to the father, such as "Complete Collection" 94: "There is a child", which means pregnancy. Since early humans often converted the words referring to children into honorific names for male dignitaries, such as the ancient Romans and the ancient Mayans living in the Americas, there were some conventions (see Lin Yuan, Qiu Xigui), so " zi " in the oracle bone inscriptions can also be used Refers to the patriarch of the same surname in Shang Dynasty. "Shang Shu. "Luogao": "Yudan uses multiple sons to make more imperial affairs." Kong Chuan refers to "multiple sons" as "all officials", which means that.

In the bronze inscriptions, " zi " can also be used as " kindness ". Such as Yuding: "Ancient (so) Tianyi (wing) Linzi (ci)" means that the heavens will cover their wings with mercy for protection. The history of the wall plate " child " and through " Zi " to "child (Zi) drain" means that urgent meaning.

During the Warring States Period, there was the title of "junzi" in the bamboo slips of Chu, which extended from the original meaning of " zi " to the suffix of the noun of human beings. Later, the original meaning of " zi " also extended to the meaning of immature and immature, such as "zijiang".
humanum_short_description_en: There are two ways to write the word "å­" in Jinwen. One is written as " ğ¢€ˆ ", which is like a newborn child with hair on the head, the fontanelle is not closed, and the shape of two feet underneath; the other is called "å­" It highlights the babyâ€™s big head, frequent arms swinging, and underdeveloped feet. The original meaning of making characters is baby.

origin_of_ch_char_book: In ancient times people made a rope by combining straws one after another. When they made ropes, they thought of the ropes as symbolizing the descendants because of how the rope continues on. The (å­«, å­™, sun, grandchild) reflects their thoughts. The character symbolizes â€œgrandchildâ€ by combining child (å­, zi=tzu, child) and rope (çµ², ä¸, si=ssu, silk). These two combinations came to mean future generation, the descendants, or a grandchild.,What do you think (èº«, shen, body) is? It used to mean a pregnant woman with a child inside her. Now it means â€œbodyâ€. At long last, the woman gives birth to a baby. describes a woman giving birth to a child (å­, zi=tzu, child), bleeding blood . This character has changed to (è‚², yu=yÃ¼, give birth to, bring up), a newborn child and flesh (è‚‰, rou, flesh), meaning that a new born child is gradually growing up. After giving birth, she breastfeeds the baby. shows a mother with her breast out to feed the baby and the baby trying to suckle. A mother embracing the child feels so happy, this character means â€˜goodâ€™, â€˜likeâ€™. And the shape was also changed as (å¥½, hao, good;love).,In ancient East Asia, women often carried their children on their backs. The baby feels protected and attached to the mother in this way (ä¿, bao, protect). This symbol combines a human (äºº, ren, human) with a child on the right (å­, zi=tzu, child) and two points which indicate a pair of hands holding the child. It shows a human carrying a child on his/her back. Now the word has come to mean to â€œprotectâ€. On the other hand, (æ£„, å¼ƒ, qi=châ€™i, abandon) shows a different scene. A child (å­, zi=tzu, child), just born with blood on the skin, is on top of a straw basket (å…¶, qi=châ€™i, that) and two hands are holding them from below. What is going on? Many people had to abandon their babies due to illness or famine when food was scarce. This character describes such a sad situation. Someone is throwing his/her baby in the basket.

Heisig constituents: child
Heisig: This kanji is a pictograph of a child wrapped up in one of those handy cocoons that Japanese mothers fix to their backs to carry around young children who cannot get around by themselves. The first stroke is like a wee head popping out for air; the second shows the body and legs all wrapped up; and the final stroke shows the arms sticking out to cling to the mother's neck.
* As a primitive, the meaning of child is retained, though you might imagine a little older child, able to run around and get into more mischief.
Chinese: Pictograph of a child. The body looks like the number seven (a childhood age) and the horizontal stroke going through it are the arms.
koohii1: A child who is ten will still ask for his ma (top looks a bit like katakana ma).
koohii2: A pictograph of a child, with arms outstretched for mother (or perhaps because she is chasing a rat?). Note that this kanji occupies the first space on the Zodiac circle, and is the sign for the rat (such as 2008!).

Elaboration: In the bronze inscription, the character " ğ¢€ˆ" resembles a newborn child with hair on the head and two feet underneath (such as åˆ©ç°‹). This configuration is more complicated and used as the first " child" of the earthly branches. Since the word " ğ¢€ˆ" is very commonly used in oracle bone inscriptions, there are also simplified glyphs, such as omitting the two legs. In oracle bone inscriptions, Simplified Chinese was used in the early days, but the more complicated traditional forms were used in the late. After the beginning of the week, the " ğ¢€ˆ" used as the number one earthly branch was often replaced with " zi", and the shape of " ğ¢€ˆ" gradually disappeared. As for the character " å­", like a child with a larger head waving his hands, the direction of the ancient characters is often not fixed, so the character " å­" can be written to the left or right. The word " å­" can be used to indicate a boy or the sixth position of the earthly branch (ie, the word " si" in later generations). Since the word " ğ¢€ˆ" used as the number one earthly branch is gradually replaced by " zi", there are two " zi" in the oracle bone inscriptions. To avoid confusion after Zhou, the word " Si" was used to denote the sixth position of the earthly branches. " Child" originally refers to an appellation relative to the father, such as "Complete Collection" 94: "There is a child", which means pregnancy. Since early humans often converted the words referring to children into honorific names for male dignitaries, such as the ancient Romans and the ancient Mayans living in the Americas, there were some conventions (see Lin Yuan, Qiu Xigui), so " zi" in the oracle bone inscriptions can also be used Refers to the patriarch of the same surname in Shang Dynasty. "Shang Shu. "Luogao": "Yudan uses multiple sons to make more imperial affairs." Kong Chuan refers to "multiple sons" as "all officials", which means that. In the bronze inscriptions, " zi" can also be used as " kindness". Such as Yuding: "Ancient (so) Tianyi (wing) Linzi (ci)" means that the heavens will cover their wings with mercy for protection. The history of the wall plate " child" and through " Zi" to "child (Zi) drain" means that urgent meaning. During the Warring States Period, there was the title of "junzi" in the bamboo slips of Chu, which extended from the original meaning of " zi" to the suffix of the noun of human beings. Later, the original meaning of " zi" also extended to the meaning of immature and immature, such as "zijiang".

Animal eggs: roe. Silkworm.
Young, small: chicken. Son animal. Sub-city.
Small, hard, granular things: bullets (d åˆµ). Chess pieces.
Contrast with "mother": Zijin (interest). Snap button. Consonants (consonants).
Name of person: man. wife. Scholars (students). Boatman (boatman). Gifted.
The honorific name for people in ancient times; the teacher or the moral and knowledgeable person: Confucius. The pre-Qin philosophers.
The first place of the earthly branches belongs to the rat: Zi Chou Yinmao (a metaphor for the orderly level or order of things).
Used for timing: midnight (11 o'clock to one o'clock at night). Midnight (late night).
The fourth class of the fifth class of the feudal system: Viscount.
Attached to nouns, verbs, and adjectives, it is nominal (read softly): flag. trouble. Fat man.
Suffixes of individual quantifiers (read softly): I knocked on the door twice.

Radicals: å­  (child)
Meaning Mnemonic
The child radical and the child kanji are exactly the same.
So, if you know your radicals, you know your kanji as well! This won't last forever (where radicals are exactly the same as the kanji) so enjoy it while the kanji are still small and simple!
Reading Mnemonic
To remember the sounds ã— and ã™ we'll use these mnemonics:
There is a child standing in front of you. You look closely at the child but something seems wrong. You rub your eyes and when you open them again there is a sheep (ã—) in a suit (ã™) in front of you. You yelp, blink, and it's back to being a child. Are... all children really just sheep in suits?!
The child runs away and you chase after it. Every time it's about to turn a corner it looks like a sheep in a suit again, but whenever you yell and point, it turns back. You're the only one who can see this sheep suit child!!
